title: Alexander_Zverev
extract: Alexander "Sascha" Zverev is a German professional tennis player and the current world No. 2. He has won 23 ATP Tour titles in singles and two in doubles, and has been runner-up at three majors. His career highlights include a gold medal at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, and titles at the 2018 and the 2021 ATP Finals.

title: Pete_Carroll
extract: Peter Clay Carroll is an American professional football coach who is the head coach for the Las Vegas Raiders of the National Football League (NFL). He recently served as a senior advisor for the Seattle Seahawks. He was previously the head football coach at the University of Southern California (USC) from 2001 to 2009 and the head coach of the Seahawks from 2010 to 2023. Carroll is the third and most recent head coach to win a college football national championship and a Super Bowl along with Jimmy Johnson and Barry Switzer.

NFL: {{Winning percentage|181|131|1|record=y}} | pfrcoach = CarrPe0 | pfrexec = CarrPe0 }} '''Peter Clay Carroll''' (born September 15, 1951) is an American professional [[American football|football]] coach who is the [[head coach]] for the [[Las Vegas Raiders]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He recently served as a senior advisor for the [[Seattle Seahawks]]. He was previously the head football coach at the [[University of Southern California]] (USC) from 2001 to 2009 and the head coach of the Seahawks from 2010 to 2023. Carroll is the third and most recent head coach to win a college football national championship and a Super Bowl along with [[Jimmy Johnson (American football coach)|Jimmy Johnson]] and [[Barry Switzer]].{{Cite web |last=Willis |first=George |date=February 2, 2014 |title=Carroll could join rare company with Super Bowl title |url=https://nypost.com/2014/02/01/carroll-could-join-rare-company-with-supe-win/ |access-date=October 29, 2022 |website=New York Post |language=en-US |archive-date=September 11, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180911045025/https://nypost.com/2014/02/01/carroll-could-join-rare-company-with-supe-win/ |url-status=live }} Beginning his head coaching career on the professional level, Carroll saw minimal success with the [[New York Jets]] in 1994 and the [[New England Patriots]] from 1997 to 1999. Shifting to college football with USC, he revitalized the struggling program into a top-ranked contender, winning seven consecutive conference championships and an [[AP Trophy|AP Nat

title: Matthew_Shepard
extract: Matthew Wayne Shepard was an American student at the University of Wyoming who was beaten, tortured, and left to die near Laramie on the night of October 6, 1998. He was transported by rescuers to Poudre Valley Hospital in Fort Collins, Colorado, where he died six days later from severe head injuries sustained during the attack.
trending_reason: The Matthew Shepard article might be trending due to the upcoming anniversary of his tragic murder, which continues to spark discussions on hate crimes and LGBTQ rights.

news.title: Before Standing Up to Trump, Bishop Budde Helped Matthew Shepard's Parents Safely Lay Their Son to Rest
news.snippet: Judy and Dennis Shepard had held onto Matthew's ashes for 20 years, afraid his gravesite would be vandalized.

news.snippet: Mariann Edgar Budde – who begged Trump to show mercy to LGBTQ+ youth and immigrants – was the bishop who helped lay Matthew Shepard to rest.

news.snippet: Additionally, searches for terms like “LGBTQ+” and “transgender” on WhiteHouse.gov no longer return any results.

title: Liam_Coen
extract: Liam Coen is an American professional football coach who is the head coach for the Jacksonville Jaguars of the National Football League (NFL). He previously served as the offensive coordinator for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in the 2024 season, as well as in 2022 for the Los Angeles Rams. Before that, Coen served as an assistant coach at the University of Kentucky, University of Maine, UMass, University of Rhode Island, and Brown University.
text:
{{pp|small=yes}} {{Short description|American football player and coach (born 1985)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2024}} {{Infobox NFL biography | name = Liam Coen | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | current_team = Jacksonville Jaguars | position = [[Head coach]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1985|11|8|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Warwick, Rhode Island]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 2 | weight_lbs = 220 | high_school = [[La Salle Academy (Rhode Island)|La Salle Academy (RI)]] | college = [[UMass Minutemen football|UMass]] (2004–2008) | pastteams = * [[Alabama Vipers]] ({{afly|2010}}) | pastcoaching = * [[Brown Bears football|Brown]] (2010)
Quarterbacks coach * [[Rhode Island Rams football|Rhode Island]] (2011)
Pass game coordinator & quarterbacks coach * Brown (2012–2013)
Quarterbacks coach * [[UMass Minutemen football|UMass]] (2014–2015)

Head coach | highlights = | regular_record = {{Winning percentage|0|0|record=y}} | playoff_record = | overall_record = | pfrcoach = CoenLi0 }} '''Liam Coen''' (born November 8, 1985) is an American professional [[American football|football]] coach who is the [[head coach]] for the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He previously served as the [[offensive coordinator]] for the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] in the 2024 season, as well as in 2022 for the [[Los Angeles Rams]]. Before that, Coen served as an assistant coach at the [[Kentucky Wildcats football|University of Kentucky]], [[Maine Black Bears football|University of Maine]], [[UMass Minutemen football|UMass]], [[Rhode Island Rams football|University of Rhode Island]], and [[Brown Bears football|Brown University]]. ==Early life and playing career== Born in [[Warwick, Rhode Island]] and raised in [[South Kingstown, Rhode Island|South Kingstown]], Coen played for his father, Tim, at [[La Salle Academy (Rhode Island)|La Salle Academy]] in [[Providence, Rhode Island|Providence]] where he was named Rhode Island's Gatorade Player of the Year.{{cite web |title=La Salle graduate coaches L.A. Rams; Bringing friends to Super Bowl |url=https://turnto10.com/sports/new-england-patriots/la-salle-graduate-coaches-la-rams-bringing-friends-to-super-bowl |website=WJAR |accessdate=6 October 2020}} Coen also played [[quarterback]] at [[UMass Minutemen football|UMass]] from 2004 to 2008 where he was a four-year starter, wearing the jersey number 12 in honor of his favorite athlete, [[Tom Brady]]; he was roommates with future NFL wide receiver [[Victor Cruz (American football)|Victor Cruz]].{{cite web |title=Liam Coen living out his football dreams with the Rams |url=https://www.providencejournal.com/sports/20190129/kevin-mcnamara-liam-coen-living-out-his-football-dreams-with-rams |website=Providence Journal |accessdate=6 October 2020}}{{cite web |title=Next Joe Brady? Kentucky believes it found its man in new coordinator Liam Coen |url=https://theathletic.com/2267488/2020/12/17/liam-coen-kentucky-wildcats-offensive-coordinator-los-angeles-rams-umass-maine/ |website=The Athletic |access-date=19 December 2020}} As of February 2019, Coen holds six of the eight UMass career passing records, the other two being career interceptions and career yards per game average.{{cite web |title=Former UMass quarterback Coen gets 'unbelievable' chance to coach against idol Brady |url=https://www.berkshireeagle.com/former-umass-quarterback-coen-gets-unbelievable-chance-to-coach-against-idol-brady/article_8b70020e-1366-5776-a0a9-96f71981105d.html |website=The Berkshire Eagle |accessdate=6 October 2020}} In 2022, he was inducted into UMass Athletics Hall of Fame.{{Cite web |last=Morrison |first=Dan |date=2022-06-14 |title=Liam Coen Enters Massachusetts Athletics Hall of Fame |url=https://www.underdogdynasty.com/2022/6/14/23166177/liam-coen-enters-massachusetts-athletics-hall-of-fame-umass-foo
trending_reason: The Liam Coen article might be trending due to his recent promotion to head coach of the Jacksonville Jaguars, marking a significant step in his coaching career.

title: English_longbow
extract: The English longbow was a powerful medieval type of bow, about 6 ft (1.8 m) long. While it is debated whether it originated in England or in Wales from the Welsh bow, by the 14th century the longbow was being used by both the English and the Welsh as a weapon of war and for hunting. English longbows were effective against the French during the Hundred Years' War, particularly in the battles of Sluys (1340), Crécy (1346), Poitiers (1356), and Agincourt (1415). They were less successful later on, as longbowmen had their lines broken at the Battle of Verneuil (1424), although the English won a decisive victory there; they were completely routed at the Battle of Patay (1429) when they were charged by the French mounted men-at-arms before they had prepared the terrain and finished defensive arrangements. The Battle of Pontvallain (1370) had also previously shown longbowmen were not particularly effective when not given the time to set up defensive positions.
trending_reason: The English longbow article might be trending due to renewed interest in medieval warfare and archery, possibly sparked by recent historical documentaries or events commemorating its role in battles like Crécy and Agincourt.
